WRITING.TITLE: No personal trainer available - options?
WRITING.TEXT: Hi guys. Not here for any kind of beration, here for advice. I'm not a very big fitness bunny, but I am trying to get myself into the gym a little more (than never.) I live in Germany, and have a two year contract with a gym here. But for me a big problem is the discipline and routine of actually going to the gym, so if I know I have to meet Johanna (for example, that's not a real person) at 7pm every Wednesday to work out, I will go and meet Johanna at 7pm every Wednesday. I asked my gym trainers yesterday and they said this isn't something they offer. They instead make you a training schedule you follow by yourself, and after six weeks they take your progress. I know in my heart this isn't good for me. I just don't have enough discipline, it's been my failing so many times. Do you know of anything I can do to improve it? Is trying to find my own PT outside of the gym to bring with me an idea? TIA

gt; Find a workout buddy. That way, you still have someone to meet there and it turns the gym into a more enjoyable environment for you. I have a friend from work who offered to come with me any time I'd like to train. gt; Does your gym offer exercise classes? In England most gyms offer classes included in membership, so that's another way of having an appointment of sorts to keep. This could also help you find a workout buddy if you don't currently have anyone viable. Yes, there are also classes available. But they're in German, which isn't my native language and I struggle with a lot, and it's making me a little worried about going.

WRITING.TITLE: How to deal with a difficult co-worker?
WRITING.TEXT: I don't know where to start with this lad. He is a fairly new guy, started in mid June. He will continuously ask the same questions (what's the password for this? Should I be writing like this?) A fellow team member is getting frustrated that it's taking him this long to learn some basics. Likes the sound of his own voice. A lot. Particularly at 8am on the bus to work when this Young Wan is barely of this world. A chronic mansplainer. We work in an international department. I have, on separate occasions, seen him explain the French Revolution to French people, and tell the Dutch team all about the Netherlands. He knows all about it because he has been there once. He chews with his mouth open. It drives me utterly bananas to hear it, and another co-worker has also picked up on it. This morning he also roundabout way called a co-worker fat. This co-worker has, in recent times, lost quite a lot of weight, but because it was so much she has some extra skin that she feels insecure about. She cried in the bathroom for about 20 minutes. There are some of us who feel like we should say something. But we don't know who to (him directly/his manager/another co worker) or how to go about it. So, any tips would really be great.

WRITING.TITLE: I (26F) am growing tired of how my boyfriend (29M) acts
WRITING.TEXT: We've been together over six months, and there's a lot that frustrates me. Overall, he is a lovely guy, very supportive, and has helped me with a lot of issues. But there are niggles. He doesn't have very good standards of cleaning. Often the dishes can be left on the sideboard for DAYS with food left in them. He does the dishes maybe once or twice a week when they all pile up. He's often complained how come people with much bigger apartments or houses than his can keep on top of it, but he can't. Another thing is that he can be quite lazy at times. Take last night for example. We went to do groceries after work, with the intention to cook dinner and eat together. We got home at seven, and he went to take a nap until 9.15. By then, it was too late to eat. Today we both have the day off work. I would have loved to do something together. Get out of the house, go for a walk. Instead, he and I watched two episodes of Brooklyn 9 9 and he's taking another nap while I read on the couch. I know people talk about the honeymoon phrase ending, but is this really how it's supposed to be? Or am I just setting my standards too high? TL;DR my boyfriend can be a bit messy and lazy at times and it's starting to frustrate me.

WRITING.TITLE: Fuck being ghosted by companies
WRITING.TEXT: In January I was made redundant when my department closed down. A couple of weeks later, I saw a similar company, with whom we would have competed, advertise a similar position to the one I had previously been doing. As my old company no longer had any skin in the game in the market, I decided to apply. I went through a phone interview, a task, a Googke Hangouts call, and an in person interview in their head office. I thought everything had gone really well. I wasn't being cocky, but I knew thiswas a job I could do, and had the skills and experience for. That was on a Monday, I was told I would hear back "by the end of the week." Well, it's now two weeks later, I haven't heard anything back from them, and the posting is offline. I have been driving myself insane trying to think what aI could have done or said wrong to make them completely ghost me. At this point, IDGAF whether I got it or not. Just be polite and tell me. Because, candidates talk. Has this ever happened to anyone else here?
Calling your police captain "Dad" in front of the entire squad

Attempting bean enchiladas from BBC Good Food tonight. The night I'm entertaining guests was probably not a good night to try! Ingredients 1 tsp olive oil 2 onions, chopped 280g carrots, grated 2-3 tsp chilli powder (mild or hot, according to your taste) 2 x 400g cans chopped tomatoes 2 x 400g cans pulses in water, drained (I have mixed beans and lentils) 6 small wholemeal tortillas 200g low-fat natural yogurt 50g extra-mature cheddar cheese (or veg alternative), finely grated Method Heat the oil in a large frying pan. Cook the onions and carrots for 5-8 mins until soft #8211; add a splash of water if they start to stick. Sprinkle in the chilli powder and cook for 1 min more. Pour in the tomatoes and pulses and bring to the boil. Turn down the heat and simmer for 5-10 mins, stirring occasionally, until thickened. Remove from the heat and season well. Heat grill to high. Spread a spoonful of the bean chilli over a large ovenproof dish. Lay each tortilla onto a board, fill with a few tbsp of chilli mixture, fold over the ends and roll up to seal. Place them into the ovenproof dish. Spoon the remaining chilli on top. Mix the yogurt and grated cheese together with some seasoning, and spoon over the enchiladas. Grill for a few mins until the top is golden and bubbling.

I've also been told she can speak relatively good English (around the same level as my German, which is B1. I often struggle to understand the family when we are together, but I get by.) My partner's mother has English heritage (her father is from SE England) and we will go to see her family for a week soon. Here, she will have to speak English to them, as none of them have ay German. WIBTA for asking we speak English in our AirBnB as well, so I could understand more and to help get her out of her shell a little?

Yeah, that's something that confuses me too. That she has English heritage that close back but doesn't know a lot/doesn't feel confident to speak it. EG: if we had anything to organise with the booking over the phone, I was the one to do it because "you can speak English"
True, but when I'm in their house the opppsite is true. I am significantly out of my comfort zone, but she has said to my face the reason they do it is so I can learn and practice German.

First hand experience, or through the grapevine?) You're one of the bridesmaids, and with that comes the power to party. She is likely going to fly home before those 10 days, why not hold a hen party for her with your other American friends before she flies back? She can also have a hen at home for relations/friends from home/people who are in a position to make that party. Then, fly out yourself about three or four days before the wedding, to give you time to get over the jetlag.

We lost two cats in 2016 within six months of each other - our matriarch, Alfie, and one of her first litter, Lucky. Alfie disappeared for about three and a half weeks, two months before she actually died. We had pretty much consigned ourselves to her having made an Irish goodbye when she appeared in the gate one Friday afternoon. She did the same about eight years previous, roughly six months after we got her. Just to bookmark it. She had heart failure, and was scheduled to be put to sleep on Christmas Eve. My mother went to the vet with her, and took a surprisingly long time to come back. The car turned in the driveway and I came to the door to start my goodbyes. I noticed Alfie was in her carrier, which I found odd as when Lucky came home in that June she was on her pillow. Then I noticed her head move. In the vet surgery, Alfie had a sudden miraculous moment and was given a steroid to see her through Christmas. She passed in her sleep in the early hours of 29 December, completely ignoring she had a final journey to the vet scheduled for 8am that day. As for Lucky, she was the biggest fluffball. She wasn't a Maine Coon, but there must have been something of it in her. Lucky was friend to all, and all were a friend to Lucky. If my brother and I had a friend over, we lost Lucky to them until the friend left again. I was especially Lucky's pet though. Every Saturday morning I would hear tiny peets on the stairs leading up to my room, and then the door would push open or a "mrow?" could be heard from outside. Lucky would then jump on the bed and curl up with me for an hour or so. It was the best start to the day, and no Saturday has felt right since we said goodbye.

I have a strange egg in the race. I'm from Ireland but currently live in Germany. I like it here, it's very organised (much more so than at home), standard of living is relatively higher and the cost of living is much lower (I would never be able to afford to live on my own in Ireland, something I can comfortably do here.) However, there are still teething problems two years in. I'm still not totally fluent in German so can make errors even with official and govt. documents. A lot of my friends have left recently so it's getting lonely. For me? Right now, it would be the flip of a coin. **NB: my partner is German. I asked him too. He picked Germany. "Because I was born here."**

Year the car was registered- county it was registered in - the number car it was registered as. EG: 191 D (for Dublin) 12345 Up to 2012, the year was just the last two digits (08, 11, etc). In 2013, to ward off the superstition of having a 13 licence plate, the year was divided in two. From then on, cars registered in the first half of the year were one, and the second were two. For example, my parents both have cars from 2016. My Mam's was registered some time between January and June, so is 161. My Dad's, some time between July and December, so 162.

The Mayo Curse. Mayo's football haven't won an All Ireland since the 1950s. The last time they did, the team drove through Foxford beeping their horns and celebrating. However, there was a funeral in the town that day. The priest at the funeral cursed the team. It's said that until every man who was on that team is dead, Mayo won't win an All Ireland. There are two men still alive as of September 2019

WRITING.TITLE: I work with a female Kevin
WRITING.TEXT: There is no other way to describe this woman. Just a snippet of the Kevinisms: gt; She has been written sick since Sept 16th. In this time she has: driven **herself** to the hospital with a 40 #176; temperature. Let us remember that basal body temp is 37 #176;, 39 #176; is classed as a fever, and at 41 or 42 your organs shut down. She blacked out on the Autobahn- you know, that place where *CARS DRIVE AT WHATEVER SPEED THEY SEE FIT* and crashed. gt; Last night, she choked, couldn't breathe, and turned blue. Her mother had to come into her room to try and save her. She only decided to seek medical attention this morning. gt; I live in Germany, but am a native English speaker. On our first day, we were talking about languages. I asked if she could speak anything other than German, she said no. Odd, as lots of Germans our age (she's two years younger than me, I'm late 20s) have at least school level English, but whatever. She then had a phone conversation with her mother in perfect Arabic. She couldn't discern that German and Arabic are different languages. This woman is harmless, but one day is going to unintentionally cause her own death.
